results.title: Cheek to cheek
results.creator_credit: Beth Armstrong, Australian Film Commission and Strong Arm Films
results.brief_description: When her uncommunicative, elderly husband dies suddenly after choking on an Anzac biscuit, Beryl casts off her bereavement to rediscover pleasures she had lost touch with in the latter years of her marriage, such as swimming in the sea, tap dancing, chocolate and foolish games. The catalyst for her reinvigoration so late in life is her little dog, who metamorphosises before her eyes only, into a frisky, carefree older woman. The pair become inseparable playmates much to the consternation of Beryl’s uptight daughter who sees only a spoilt dog and fears for her mother’s sanity. A film that touches on universal themes such as life after death of a loved one, caring for the aged, discovering your other half and taking control of your own happiness. Cast includes Melissa Jaffer, Tina Bursill, Maggie Blinco and Georgina Naidui.

results.title: Chaos
results.brief_description: What makes the weather so unpredictable and volatile? Why do epidemics come and go without any discernible pattern and why do social systems, like the Stock Exchange, suffer catastrophic collapses? Could these phenomena ever be predicted? The answer may lie in an exciting mathematical theory - the Chaos Theory - put forward by an intrepid group of mathematicians and physicist. Chaos provides clues to the way in which the universe can seem both ordered and disordered at the same time. This video describes the constituent segments of the Chaos Theory and its practical applications in the real world.

results.title: Changing the needle
results.creator_credit: Martha Ansara, Dasha Ross, Mavis Robertson and Jequerity
results.brief_description: One of the consequences of the Vietnam war is a quarter million Vietnamese drug addicts. This film shot in Vietnam in 1981 shows how an underdeveloped war ravaged country is dealing with this problem. Alternative medicine such as acupuncture, natural medicines and exercises play an important part in the rehabilitation process. It also shows a society trying to cope with material scarcity and poverty - the heritage of underdevelopment and the inevitable result of war. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Changi. Eps. 4-6
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Episodes 4-6 of the television series “Changi”. Written by John Doyle, “Changi” is a series based on the capture and treatment of Australian soldiers taken in 1942 by the Japanese in Singapore. Its primary focus is on a group of men, The Secret Nine’, who battle torture, hunger, sickness and terror with laughter and good old Aussie mateship.Curley’: Curley is studying for his upcoming driving test which will allow him to keep his licence when an impatient driver behind him throws him into panic and his mind returns to Changi. The men are putting on a concert - their act is a comical one which involves dressing up as Japanese soldiers, but backfires when one of the lower ranked Japanese soldiers is offended. When Curley is caught stealing a tin of condensed milk, it’s the same young Japanese soldier who decides to humiliate him by throwing him into the Hole’ for six weeks where he experiences the constant harsh acts of the soldier.Eddie’s Birthday’: Memories come flooding back to Eddie while he is shaving one day, a ritual he used to only perform on his birthday in Changi. His memories are of the year he got an infected wisdom tooth and unwillingly attracted the attention of the cruel and malicious Captain Shindo, whom the men think is starting to go mad. `Pacifying The Angels’: It’s finally the day of the reunion and Tom loves seeing his old mates. He hates where his memory goes after spending time with them, the last night of the war. The war is officially over and the Japanese declare they have won, burning all evidence of what they have done to the men in the last 5 years. ‘The Secret Nine’ have to pull all their courage and strength together as they witness the Japanese shooting anyone they can; it will take all their might to survive the night.

results.title: Changi. Eps. 1-3
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Episodes 1-3 of the television series “Changi”. Written by John Doyle, “Changi” is a series based on the capture and treatment of Australian soldiers taken in 1942 by the Japanese in Singapore. Its primary focus is on a group of men, The Secret Nine’, who battle torture, hunger, sickness and terror with laughter and good old Aussie mateship.Seeing is believing’: The Secret Nine’s annual 9 year reunion is coming up and David (Charles Tingwell, Matthew Newton plays David during the war years) is having flashbacks of his time in the war. There is a lot he has forgotten (or blacked out), and now it’s all coming back to him. They have been captured by the Japanese having spent only two weeks in Singapore. David and the other men go to the Japanese supply store to trade a pack of sewing needles for 5 eggs and 1 tin of strawberry jam, the conditions are bad bad and they are desperate for food. The men are caught and sent back to the barracks, except for David, who manages to steal a pack of razor blades. While David is attempting to return to the camp he is captured and severely beaten - left bloodied, bruised and temporarily blinded. He is picked up by Japanese soldiers and put onto a bus with other local villages who are being taken out to to be shot. David’s mates search for him and eventually find him lying under some trees, he is concussed and sore but in a tenacious effort, still has the packet of razor blades. Gordon’s Will’: Gordon (Anthony Hayes) suffers a stroke and has flashbacks to an experience he had at Changi when he refused to salute Japanese Lieutenant Aso. Lieutenant Aso makes Gordon stand on a box in the middle of the yard and performs violent acts on him to try and force him to salute. Gordon’s friends devise a plan to try and help him but also make a few bets to their favour. It is in this episode that the origin ofSecret Nine’ is disclosed. `Private Bill’: Bill, now a University Professor, sees a young student who looks incredibly like the young girl he fell in love with before going to war. Her visit prompts Bill to reminisce about his experiences in the war. Mathematically clever, Bill is and given problems to try and solve. He builds a radio and discovers the camp will be receiving a visit from an influential general; the boys are given strict orders on how to behave while he visits. They decide to play a trick on the Colonel which will undermine his authority at the camp with the General.

results.title: Chance History Art
results.brief_description: Shows six artists at work, one of them being Jimmy Boyle, the prisoner who spends his time in prison sculpting. Three themes interweave through the film - Chance; the role of accident in painting and change in performance - History; connections with surrealism and politics - Art; the present day, the way art merges with everyday life and is mediated by institutions

results.title: Champions of the Australian Turf
results.brief_description: Captures the real stories behind Australian racing’s undisputed idols through the performances and personalities that make them great. Presented as a History of Racing, you’ll see Australia’s first race meeting in 1810, the 1866 Melbourne Cup, the Carbine story, Phar Lap’s greatest victories, Peter Pan and Chatham in the Craven Plate, Ajax winning his third Memsie Stakes, Bernborough’s amazing races, Tulloch winning the AJC Derby and Caulfield Cup, Todman - the fastest two year old, contemporary champion, Kingston Town and Beau Zam, Australia’s first $2 million earner.

results.title: Challenges and rebirth
results.creator_credit: Lin Yung, Jao Ming, Weng Jeng-Yih and Kwang Hwa Mass Communications
results.brief_description: Documents the achievements of the Taiwanese people since the establishment of the Republic of China in 1949. The transition was difficult, but through hard work and dedication, Taiwan made its mark on the world marketplace. In the 21st Century, the Taiwanese are dedicated to further developing their “laissez-faire’ economy and democratic reforms.

results.title: Cell division in the diatom pinnularia
results.creator_credit: David Tippit, Jeremy Pickett-Heaps, Tom Soranno and Cytographics Productions
results.brief_description: Uses electron micrography, polarisation optics and other techniques to show cell division in the Diatom Pinnularia. Each stage in the process is described and explained

results.title: Cell 16
results.creator_credit: Martin Duckworth, Colin Low and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Filmed at Collins Bay Penitentiary, Kingston, Ontario, this is a portrayal of the effects on the individual of incarceration. Prisons, the film shows, lock men in themselves, depriving their minds of normal life experiences, confiscating their humanity. Music - Eugene Grandmond and The Fifth Dimension. Voice and narration by Jim Morrison.
